a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:10): about John's comment, this part: "the demand for XForms is such that IBM has decided not to wait for web browser makers to define the web. Just as Ajax libraries like Dojo are coming to define the new face of web application development"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:11): I've seen several different people saying things quite similar to that lately
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:11): seems like they may have gotten together and decided to use it as a common message
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:12): to suggest that browser vendors are no longer innovating and can be safely ignored (or something)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:13): which would seem like sort of a convenient view to have if you were working on specs without actively trying to get browser vendors involved in the work on those specs
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:17): the thing is, John's comments don't actually refute what David says
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:17): Mozilla obviously hasn't seen enough demand to balance the cost of writing/testing/offering/permanently supporting the code in Firefox
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:18): because if they had, then they would be trying to meet it
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:22): it also sounds like XForms is being deployed in intranet apps, not interweb apps, so it seems like a plugin would do there anyway

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:23): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: yeah, I think John doesn't address the issue that the cost of actually implementing is just one part of the overall cost. maybe just a small part of the cost, looking at it long-term
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:23): I personally think a lot of Web developers would really like to have native XForms support and could come up with some great applications to make use of it
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:24): I don't really know what can't be done now that could be done with XForms
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:25): all their advertising is about schemas and XML
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:25): I guess it's a matter of what could possibly be done more easily than it could be now
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:25): yeah, it's definitely not to their advantage to advertise those aspects
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:27): I think the big advantages from XForms would come only if it were implemented interoperably across browsers
056705610ffb1726be04db950e5feebe (12:28): plugs http://standardssuck.org upcoming episode "W3C Digging the XML Grave" ... should be out later today!
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:28): I guess I just don't see the need for a paradigm shift in the way forms are used on the web
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:29): I don't see a need for a paradigm shift, either.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:29): web forms 2 seems to hit the sweet spot, more-or-less

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:29): so it would allow developers who wante to use declarative approach for buidling cross-browser apps. that is, leaving heavy lifting up to the browser instead of needing to do it themselves in JS code
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:29): however, for Ajax app, it makes sense to implement MVC in JS instead of relying on an XForms engine providing one blessed MVC engine
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:30): I think XForms is meant to be useful for more than just forms
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:30): it has evolved that way, anyway
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:30): 056705610ffb1726be04db950e5feebe: what's the grave? 5th ed.?

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:32): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: anyway, I'm playing devil's advocate here. it seems at this point that there's not much likelihood of XForms getting implemented natively across browsers is

b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:33): I guess I'm just not sold on declarative languages full stop.  code and data aren't as distinct as people would like to think they are, IME, and web forms 2 seems to do about the right thing (move from JS->HTML for really common things)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:33): the problem with being declarative is that once you escape to JS even a little (the XForms group showed interest in XHR for instance), the main selling points of being declarative get poisoned
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:33): so one might as well embrace JS from the getgo
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:34): (hmm. I guess I just ended up arguing against the WF2 repetition templates)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:35): yeah, the work on declarative approaches seems to be bases on a hypothesis that declarative approaches are absolutely better and that many or most developers would prefer them, given a choice
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:36): but there does not seem to be a huge amount of data to support that hypothesis
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:36): and some that seems to disprove it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:36): for example, the popularity of <canvas> among developers
